nodes.text: High public and external debt levels have systemic nonlinear effects on economic growth and inflation
Method: Assembled a multi-country historical dataset on central government debt covering 44 countries, about 200 years, and over 3,700 annual observations

Result: For advanced economies, public debt above roughly 90 percent of GDP is associated with median GDP growth about 1 percentage point lower and mean growth nearly 4 percentage points lower compared with lower debt ranges

Result: For emerging market countries, public debt above roughly 90 percent of GDP also coincides with markedly lower median and average GDP growth (median falls to about 2.9 percent from around 4–4.5 percent), and higher inflation

Result: For emerging markets, gross external debt thresholds are lower than public debt thresholds: when external debt reaches 60 percent of GDP annual growth declines by about 2 percent, and when external debt exceeds 90 percent growth rates are roughly cut in half

Evidence: The 2007–2009 period saw large increases in central government debt—about 75 percent increase in average debt for five crisis countries and about 20 percent increase for non-crisis countries between 2007 and 2009
Claim: Rapid postcrisis public debt buildups are a key legacy of deep financial crises and can have long-run macroeconomic costs given demographics and rising social insurance costs
Method: Used grouping of annual observations into debt/GDP ranges (below 30%, 30–60%, 60–90%, above 90%) to compare average and median GDP growth and inflation across groups
Claim: The relationship between very high public debt and lower growth is remarkably similar across advanced and emerging economies for public debt thresholds

Claim: Inflation response differs by country type: advanced economies show no systematic link between high public debt and inflation as a group, while emerging markets show significantly higher inflation at high public or external debt levels (fiscal dominance plausible)
Limitation: Unable to calculate comparable total external debt thresholds for advanced countries because the external debt time series for advanced countries is only available from 2000

Conclusion: High debt/GDP levels (about 90% for public debt, lower for external debt in emerging markets) are associated with notably lower growth outcomes and pose vulnerabilities that merit prudent debt management and avoidance of excessive short-term borrowing

Claim: Private sector debt dynamics matter—postcrisis private deleveraging (example US private debt falls after booms) can further depress growth and raise unemployment, adding to the drag from public indebtedness
